title: Mixed Compliance Samples
vignette: A lab tech buys two test kits—one mandatory safety test, one voluntary certification—but forgets which is which after the boxes are mixed.

options.text: Use all samples for safety testing and purchase new kits for the voluntary certification.
Split them: one for safety testing, one for certification regardless of uncertainty.

title: Two Clients' Kits Mixed
vignette: Required and voluntary test kits belonging to two different clients accidentally get shuffled together on the packing bench.

options.text: Allocate one safety and one certification test for each client.
Require both clients to purchase entirely new test kits.

title: One sample damaged
vignette: From a designated pair of samples, one becomes contaminated before testing.

options.text: Replace only the damaged sample and proceed.
Use a whole new pair to avoid doubt.

title: Forgotten Labels on Paired Kits
vignette: A donor purchases two kits but loses track of which kit was intended for which test type before submission.

options.text: Designate them now and continue.
Purchase a fresh pair with clear intent.

title: Technician Swaps One Kit from Each Pair
vignette: During preparation, a technician accidentally swaps one sample between two paired orders, mixing their intended purposes.

options.text: Process each mixed pair as is, using majority designation.
Invalidate both pairs and start over.

title: Voluntary samples mixed with mandatory
vignette: A voluntary certification sample falls into a tray of mandatory safety test samples.

options.text: Count one sample as the voluntary test and proceed.
Discard the entire group and bring new samples.

title: Wrong Verbal Label During Processing
vignette: A technician starts processing a sample but verbally calls out the wrong test type midway through the procedure.

options.text: The sample is invalid and must be replaced.
Correct the designation mid-process and continue.

title: Large Batch of Mixed Kits
vignette: Dozens of kits of both mandatory and voluntary categories get dumped into one tray; staff can't tell them apart.

options.text: Treat all as voluntary certification tests and request new mandatory pairs.
Randomly assign safety and certification tests until numbers match.

title: Damaged sample in the group
vignette: One sample in a designated pair becomes unusable before testing.

options.text: Replace the damaged sample only.
Replace the entire pair to maintain consistency.

title: Unsure If Kit Already Tested
vignette: A client is not certain whether her two required kits have already been processed or are still pending.

options.text: Submit another pair to remove any doubt.
Assume they were tested and submit nothing.

title: Sample Escapes and Returns
vignette: A tagged carrier pigeon with a micro-sample escapes the rooftop lab and flies back later; staff are unsure it's the same specimen.

options.text: Accept it as the original and proceed.
Replace it to avoid any mix-up.

title: Two pairs merged then separated
vignette: Sample pairs from two different test orders merge in a tray, then the samples are separated again but staff are unsure which belong to whom.

options.text: Assign randomly and proceed.
Consider all samples compromised and require new pairs.

title: Premium vs Standard Kits
vignette: A client paid for premium-grade test kits but receives standard-grade ones instead.

options.text: Accept the samples; quality doesn't affect validity.
Demand replacement samples matching the price paid.

title: Age-Specific Species Swap
vignette: Two specimen types have age-dependent validity rules. During handling, containers are swapped so age compliance is unknown.

options.text: Process as is since both specimen types are allowed.
Replace to match the original specimen type intended.

title: Excess samples purchased
vignette: A donor accidentally buys an extra pair of test kits beyond what is needed.

options.text: Use the extras as voluntary certification tests.
Return them for refund and keep only the required tests.
